topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Karina Nguyen and her work at OpenAI and Anthropic, framing the episode around how frontier AI products and models are built and where work is heading.

topics.title: Sponsor Break: Enterpret and Vanta
topics.summary: Sponsor messages covering Enterpret’s customer-feedback analytics platform and Vanta’s compliance automation, including listener discounts.

topics.title: Why model training is an art
topics.summary: Karina explains common misunderstandings about model creation: training is like debugging software, heavily driven by data quality and balancing helpfulness vs safety. She shares an example where conflicting training signals (no body vs function calls) confuse the model.

topics.title: Data walls, post-training, and synthetic data
topics.summary: They discuss the 'running out of data' concern, with Karina arguing post-training and reinforcement learning over tasks can scale beyond pretraining limits. She notes the bottleneck shifting toward better evaluations as benchmarks saturate.

topics.title: How Canvas was trained with synthetic behaviors
topics.summary: Karina breaks down Canvas development into three core trained behaviors: when to trigger Canvas, how to perform targeted vs full-document edits, and how to generate useful inline comments. She describes using o1 to generate synthetic conversations/documents and measuring progress with robust evals.

topics.title: Day-to-day work: prompting, debugging, and roles
topics.summary: Karina describes spending time prompting models to discover failure modes and ideas, then translating that into training and eval work. She also notes her shift from mostly IC research to more mentorship/management while still coding and running experiments.

topics.title: Evals in product development workflows
topics.summary: They explore how product teams define 'correct' behavior via deterministic pass/fail checks (e.g., scheduling) and human preference testing (win rates). Karina explains practical artifacts like spreadsheets that can serve both evaluation and training inputs.

topics.title: Prompting as prototyping and micro-experiences
topics.summary: Karina argues prompting is a new prototyping medium for PMs/designers, citing examples like file uploads, personalized starter prompts, and conversation title generation tuned to a user’s style.

topics.title: How OpenAI ships tools like Tasks
topics.summary: Karina explains how features like Tasks and Canvas start from a spec/prototype, then become tool schemas (e.g., JSON extraction for time/instructions), staffed by cross-functional teams, and iterated quickly. She emphasizes synthetic data for scalable iteration and shifting datasets based on beta user behavior.

topics.title: Sponsor Break: Loom
topics.summary: Sponsor message describing Loom’s screen-recording product for async communication, editing, and AI features, with a listener link.

topics.title: Researchers vs model designers at OpenAI
topics.summary: Karina distinguishes product research from longer-horizon research: developing general methods, building more sophisticated evals for generalization, and tackling open problems like increasing diversity in synthetic data.

topics.title: How work changes as intelligence gets cheaper
topics.summary: Karina predicts the cost of reasoning will keep dropping via distillation and smarter small models, expanding access and unblocking intelligence-bottlenecked work in healthcare, education, and research. She reflects on shifting from engineering to research after seeing rapid coding gains.

topics.title: Soft skills and creativity as durable advantages
topics.summary: They discuss which skills will matter most for product teams: creative idea generation, listening to users, rapid iteration, prioritization, and collaboration. Karina argues aesthetics and truly creative writing/design remain hard to train, and that management and compute allocation are key bottlenecks in AI progress.

topics.title: AI strategy, self-improvement, and organizational scaling
topics.summary: Karina agrees AI can increasingly synthesize large inputs (feedback, metrics) into strategic recommendations and may become self-improving by generating plans and training data. They close on the idea that organizational effectiveness and management decisions can bottleneck frontier progress.
